abilities.title: General Knowledge
abilities.description: Knowledge that is familiar to most members of society or is important enough that most adults have been exposed to it.
abilities.note: This is highly related to the broad CHC abilities "Comprehension-Knowledge (Gc)" and "Domain-Specific Knowledge (Gkn)."

subcategories.name: Commonsense
subcategories.description: The vast set of shared, obvious background knowledge about how the world works.

fullContent.definition: Commonsense is the vast set of shared, obvious background knowledge about how the world works.
fullContent.testingNote: Text input, text output; no partial credit. External tools (e.g., search) are disabled.
fullContent.note: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "General Verbal Information (K0)."
examples: (Intuitive Physics) "If you drop a glass bottle on a concrete floor, what is the most likely outcome?"
(Procedural Knowledge) "Describe the typical sequence of actions when preparing to board a commercial airplane once you arrive at an airport."
(Temporal Commonsense) "Does making a sandwich usually take longer than baking a loaf of bread?"
(Commonsense Morality/Cognitive Empathy) "Would people typically get mad if they found out a person burned children for the fun of it?"
tests: System performance on PIQA must exceed 85% accuracy.
System performance on ETHICS Commonsense Morality must exceed 80% accuracy.

subcategories.name: Science
subcategories.description: Knowledge of the natural and physical sciences.

fullContent.definition: Knowledge of the natural and physical sciences. Proficiency is tested without assuming knowledge of calculus. We give three opportunities to demonstrate proficiency in aspects of science: physics, chemistry, and biology. The AGI score is 1% if the model is proficient in exactly one of these subjects. The AGI score is 2% if it is proficient in two or more of these subjects.
fullContent.note: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "General Science Information (K1)."

subcategories.name: Physics
examples: A 2 kg object is moving at a constant velocity of 3 m/s. What is the net force acting on the object?
A resistor has a resistance of 10 ohms and is connected to a 5-volt battery. What is the current flowing through the resistor?
Water flows through a horizontal pipe that narrows. Where the pipe is narrower, is the water's speed higher or lower? Is the pressure higher or lower?
subcategories.test: A score of 5 on both the AP Physics 1 and Physics 2 is sufficient for the 1%, subject to memorization and robustness checks.

subcategories.name: Chemistry
examples: State the molecular geometry for the sulfur tetrafluoride molecule.
Arrange the following substances in order of increasing vapor pressure at a given temperature: CH‚ÇÉCH‚ÇÇCH‚ÇÇOH (1-propanol), CH‚ÇÉOCH‚ÇÉ (dimethyl ether), and CH‚ÇÉCH‚ÇÇOH (ethanol).
Calculate the pH of a 0.25 M solution of sodium acetate (NaCH‚ÇÉCOO). The acid dissociation constant, K‚Çê, for acetic acid (CH‚ÇÉCOOH) is 1.8 √ó 10‚Åª‚Åµ.
subcategories.test: A score of 5 on the AP Chemistry test is sufficient for the 1%, subject to memorization and robustness checks.

subcategories.name: Biology
examples: Which molecule is the final electron acceptor in the electron transport chain of cellular respiration, and what molecule is formed as a result?

The forelimbs of a human, a bat, and a whale all have a similar bone structure, even though they are used for very different functions (grasping, flying, and swimming, respectively). What is the term for these types of structures?

In pea plants, the allele for purple flowers (P) is dominant to the allele for white flowers (p). If two heterozygous (Pp) pea plants are crossed, what is the expected phenotypic ratio of their offspring?
subcategories.test: A score of 5 on the AP Biology test is sufficient for the 1%, subject to memorization and robustness checks.

subcategories.name: Social Science
subcategories.description: Understanding of human behavior, societies, and institutions.

fullContent.definition: Understanding of human behavior, societies, and institutions. We give five opportunities to demonstrate proficiency in aspects of social science: psychology, microeconomics, and macroeconomics, geography, and comparative government. The AGI score is 1% if the model is proficient in exactly one of these subjects. The AGI score is 2% if it is proficient in two or more of these subjects.
fullContent.testingNote: Only the text modality is tested.
fullContent.note: This is related to the narrow CHC ability "Geography Achievement (A5)."

subcategories.name: Psychology
examples: Name the Big Five personality traits.
Which part of the brain is most associated with fear and emotional responses such as aggression?
subcategories.test: A score of 5 on the AP Psychology test is sufficient for the 1%, subject to memorization and robustness checks.

subcategories.name: Microeconomics
examples: A firm's total cost is $500, and its fixed cost is $200. If it produces 10 units, what is its average variable cost?
Define a positive externality and provide an example.
subcategories.test: A score of 5 on the AP Microeconomics test is sufficient for the 1%, subject to memorization and robustness checks.

subcategories.name: Macroeconomics
examples: If the reserve requirement is 20%, what is the maximum potential expansion of the money supply from a new $1,000 deposit?
What is the difference between the nominal interest rate and the real interest rate?
subcategories.test: A score of 5 on the AP Macroeconomics test is sufficient for the 1%, subject to memorization and robustness checks.

subcategories.name: Geography
examples: What is the difference between a centripetal force and a centrifugal force in a state?
What happens to birth and death rates in Stage 3 of the demographic transition model?
subcategories.test: A score of 5 on the AP Human Geography test is sufficient for the 1%, subject to memorization and robustness checks.

subcategories.name: Comparative Government
examples: What is the primary difference between a presidential system and a parliamentary system?
Describe the role of the Guardian Council in Iran.
subcategories.test: A score of 5 on the AP Comparative Government and Politics test is sufficient for the 1%, subject to memorization and robustness checks.

subcategories.name: History
subcategories.description: Knowledge of past events and objects.

fullContent.definition: Knowledge of past events and objects. We give four opportunities to demonstrate proficiency in aspects of history: European history, US history, world history, and art history. The AGI score is 1% if the model is proficient in exactly one of these subjects. The AGI score is 2% if it is proficient in two or more of these subjects.
fullContent.testingNote: The text and image modalities are tested.

subcategories.name: European History
examples: What were the main goals of the Congress of Vienna in 1815?
Explain the political, social, and religious causes of the Thirty Years' War.
subcategories.test: A score of 5 on the AP European History test is sufficient for the 1%, subject to memorization and robustness checks.

subcategories.name: US History
examples: Explain the concept of Manifest Destiny and its impact on westward expansion in the 19th century.
Analyze the goals and strategies of the Civil Rights Movement of the 1950s and 1960s.
subcategories.test: A score of 5 on the AP US History test is sufficient for the 1%, subject to memorization and robustness checks.

subcategories.name: World History
examples: Discuss the rise and impact of the Ottoman Empire from the 14th to the 20th centuries.
Describe the end of the Cold War.
subcategories.test: A score of 5 on the AP World History test is sufficient for the 1%, subject to memorization and robustness checks.

subcategories.name: Art History
examples: Discuss the use of contrapposto in ancient Greek and Roman sculpture, using specific examples.
Explain how the Benin Bronzes reflect the political and religious power of the Oba.
subcategories.test: A score of 5 on the AP Art History test is sufficient for the 1%, subject to memorization and robustness checks.

subcategories.name: Culture
subcategories.description: Cultural literacy and awareness.

fullContent.definition: This evaluates cultural literacy and awareness. It is divided into Current Affairs (1%) and Popular Culture (1%).
fullContent.note: The examples below are US-centric. This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "General Verbal Information (K0)."

subcategories.name: Current Affairs
subcategories.description: Knowledge of recent, significant events and contemporary issues.
examples: Who is the current president of the United States of America?
Has the US economy been in a recession for the past year?
Is Microsoft's market cap over five trillion dollars?
Are Russia and Ukraine at war?

subcategories.name: Popular Culture
subcategories.description: Knowledge of widely recognized art, music, literature, media, and public figures.
subcategories.testingNote: Text, audio, and visual modalities tested.
examples: Who is this?
I'll play the first part of a song. Tester plays the first 18 seconds of White Christmas üîä so that the listener just hears "I'm dreaming of a White". What word does he say next?
"Is this a highly well-known musical piece, namely a piece that most people in the country have heard?" Tester plays Magmoor Caverns üîä. Answer: No.

abilities.title: Reading and Writing Ability
abilities.description: Reading and writing ability captures all of the declarative knowledge and procedural skills a person uses to consume and produce written language.
abilities.note: This is highly related to the broad CHC ability "Reading and Writing (Grw)."

subcategories.name: Letter-Word Ability
subcategories.description: The ability to recognize letters and decode words.

fullContent.definition: This is the ability to recognize letters and decode words.
fullContent.testingNote: Text input, text output for all testing.
fullContent.note: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "Reading Decoding (RD)."
examples: Which two letters match exactly? Bb Dd Aa aa
What letter is missing in do_r?
Which letter is facing the correct way? m m t (with reversed letters)
How many "r's" are in "raspberry"?
How many syllables are in the word refrigerator?
Count the number of ts in "tennessee".

subcategories.name: Reading Comprehension
subcategories.description: The ability to understand connected discourse during reading.

fullContent.definition: This is the ability to understand connected discourse during reading. Systems must also be able to determine if a question is underdetermined by the context. We split reading comprehension into three levels: sentence level (1%), paragraph level (1%), and document level (1%).
fullContent.testingNote: Text input, text output for all testing.
fullContent.note: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "Reading Comprehension (RC)."
examples: Sentence Level: Read the sentence: "The trophy would not fit in the brown suitcase because it was too large." What was too large?

Paragraph Level: Read the paragraph: "Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun. It is often referred to as the 'Red Planet' because the iron oxide prevalent on its surface gives it a reddish appearance. This rust is a key feature of its landscape." Why is Mars called the Red Planet?

Document Level: Read the following product manual excerpt: "...Protect the motor, display and battery against extreme temperatures... A two-year warranty applies to the battery. Should a fault occur during this period, your Gazelle specialist will replace the battery. Normal aging as well as wear and tear..." What is the warranty period for the battery? (Full document here üìÑ)
tests: Sentence Level: Reliably solving Winograd schemas is sufficient for the 1%. For example, >85% accuracy on WinoGrande strongly suggests proficiency.
Paragraph Level: Model accuracy on COQA must exceed 85%, ReCoRD accuracy must exceed 90%, and LAMBADA accuracy must exceed 80% (zero shot).

Document Level: Model accuracy exceeding 55% on LongBench v2 suggests proficiency. Since models must determine if a question is underdetermined, it should also have a hallucination rate of less than 1% on Vectara HHEM.

subcategories.name: Writing Ability
subcategories.description: Ability to write with clarity of thought, organization, and good sentence structure.

fullContent.definition: Ability to write with clarity of thought, organization, and good sentence structure. We split writing ability into three levels: sentence level (1%), paragraph level (1%), and essay level (1%).
fullContent.testingNote: Text input, text output for all testing.
fullContent.note: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "Writing Ability (WA)."
examples: Sentence Level: Write a single sentence using the words "ocean," "moon," and "tide."
Paragraph Level: Write a paragraph discussing the benefits of regular exercise.
Essay Level: Write a well-structured essay arguing for or against the proposition that remote work should be the default option for office-based jobs.
tests: If the model receives a 4 or greater out of 6 on GRE Analytical Writing prompts, then that is sufficient for 3%, subject to memorization and robustness checks.

subcategories.name: English Usage Knowledge
subcategories.description: Knowledge of writing in the English language with respect to capitalization, punctuation, usage, and spelling.

fullContent.definition: This is knowledge of writing in the English language with respect to capitalization, punctuation, usage, and spelling. We split English usage knowledge into three levels: sentence level (1%), paragraph level (1%), and document level (1%). Document level English usage knowledge can be operationalized as proofreading a multipage document.
fullContent.testingNote: Text input, text output for all testing.
fullContent.note: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "English Usage (EU)."
examples: Sentence Level: Is the following sentence grammatically acceptable? "I bought an Italian hunting blue little antique beautiful cap."
Paragraph Level: Find the typos in this: Example paragraph with intentional typos (link here üìÑ).
Document Level: Find the typos in this: Example with five intentional typos (link here üìÑ), example with six intentional typos (link here üìÑ).
tests: For sentence-level English usage knowledge, it is necessary that AI systems be able to achieve greater than a 60% correlation on the Corpus of Linguistic Acceptability.

abilities.title: Mathematical Ability
abilities.description: This is the depth and breadth of mathematical knowledge and skills.
abilities.note: This is highly related to the broad CHC ability "Quantitative Knowledge (Gq)" and the narrow abilities Mathematical Knowledge (KM), Mathematical Achievement (A3), and General Sequential Reasoning (RG).

subcategories.name: Arithmetic
subcategories.description: The manipulation of numbers using basic operations and solving word problems.

fullContent.definition: Arithmetic is the branch of mathematics that deals with the properties and manipulation of numbers using the four basic operations: addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. Rudimentary arithmetic accounts for 1% and covers evaluating arithmetic expressions with numbers up to five digits. Proficiency in arithmetic accounts for 1% and covers solving basic arithmetic word problems.
examples: Rudimentary Illustrative Examples:
What is $19 + 11$?
What is 2,405 times 61?
What is 15,267 divided by 721?
Proficient Illustrative Examples:

Janet had 22 green pens and 10 yellow pens. Then she bought 6 bags of blue pens and 2 bags of red pens. There were 9 pens in each bag of blue and 6 pens in each bag of red. How many pens does Janet have now?

Answer: 98 (GSM8K)

A company's HR hires 20 new employees every month to add to its total workforce. If the company's initial employee number is 200, and each employee is paid a $4000 salary per month, calculate the total amount of money the company pays to its employees after three months?

Answer: 2880000 (GSM8K)
tests: Greater than 95% on GSM8K is sufficient for the 2%, subject to memorization and robustness checks.

subcategories.name: Algebra
subcategories.description: The study of symbols and the rules for combining them to express general relationships and solve equations.

fullContent.definition: Algebra studies symbols and the rules for combining them to express general relationships and solve equations. Rudimentary algebra accounts for 1% and covers SAT-level algebra problems. Proficiency in algebra accounts for 1% and covers competition-level (MathCounts State/Nationals) algebra problems.
examples: Rudimentary Illustrative Examples:

Let $g(x)=ax^2+24$, where a is a constant. If $g(4)=8$, what is $g(-4)$?

Answer: 8

A grocery's prices (in dollars per pound) change linearly with $x$, the number of weeks after July 1. Beef: $b(x) = 2.35 + 0.25x$. Chicken: $c(x) = 1.75 + 0.40x$. (a) For what value of x are the prices equal? (b) What is the common price?

Answer: (a) 4 weeks, (b) $3.35 per lb
Proficient Illustrative Examples:

The first three terms of a geometric sequence are the integers a, 720, b, where a < 720 < b. What is the sum of the digits of the least possible value of b?
(A) 9
(B) 12
(C) 16
(D) 18
(E) 21
Answer: E (21)

Integers a, b, and c satisfy ab + c = 100, bc + a = 87, and ca + b = 60. What is ab + bc + ca?
(A) 212
(B) 247
(C) 258
(D) 276
(E) 284
Answer: D (276)
tests: Greater than 90% on MATH Algebra is sufficient for the 2%, subject to memorization and robustness checks.

subcategories.name: Geometry
subcategories.description: The study of shapes, space, size, position, and distance.

fullContent.definition: Geometry is the branch of mathematics that studies shapes and space, including size, position, and distance. Rudimentary geometry accounts for 1% and covers SAT-level geometry problems. Proficiency in geometry accounts for 1% and covers competition-level (MathCounts State/Nationals) geometry problems.
examples: Rudimentary Illustrative Examples:

What is the value of w in the figure?


Answer: 100 degrees (source)

A square and an equilateral triangle have equal perimeters. If the square has sides of length 3, what is the length of one side of the triangle?

Answer: 4 (source)

If the volume of a cube is 8, what is the shortest distance from the center of the cube to the base of the cube?
(A) 1
(B) 2
(C) 4
(D) $\sqrt{2}$
(E) $2\sqrt{2}$
Answer: A (1) (source)
Proficient Illustrative Example:

An orange shaded rectangle is inscribed in a quarter-circle. Two sides of the rectangle lie along the two perpendicular radii of the quarter-circle, and the rectangle's edge touches the quarter-circle arc. Two segments are given as 2 and 4 units, as shown below. What is the area of the orange shaded rectangle?


Answer: 48 (source)
tests: Greater than 95% on MATH Geometry is sufficient for the 2%, subject to memorization and robustness checks.

subcategories.name: Probability
subcategories.description: The quantification of uncertainty by assigning numbers from 0 to 1 to events.

fullContent.definition: Probability quantifies uncertainty by assigning numbers from 0 to 1 to events. Rudimentary probability accounts for 1% and covers SAT-level probability problems. Proficiency in probability accounts for 1% and covers undergraduate probability calculations.
examples: Rudimentary Illustrative Examples:

A certain hospital currently contains 319 patients, 25 nurses, 8 doctors, and 48 visiting family members. If a person is picked at random from every person currently in the hospital, which of the following choices is closest to the probability that they are a nurse?
(A) .063
(B) .066
(C) .25
(D) 16
Answer: (A) .063 (source)

When one student is chosen at random from the Debate Club, the probability that a boy is chosen is 2/5. There are currently 25 students on the Debate Club. How many boys would have to join the club in order for the probability of choosing a boy at random to be 1/2?
(A) 3
(B) 2
(C) 5
(D) 1
(E) 4
Answer: (C) 5 (source)
Proficient Illustrative Examples:

Suppose an airline accepted 12 reservations for a commuter plane with 10 seats. They know that 7 reservations went to regular commuters who will show up for sure. The other 5 passengers will show up with a 50% chance, independently of each other. (a) Find the probability that the flight will be overbooked, i.e., more passengers will show up than seats are available. (b) Find the probability that there will be empty seats. (c) Let X be the number of passengers turned away. Find E(X).

Answer: (a) 0.1875, (b) 0.5, (c) 0.219

Suppose N dice are rolled, where $1 \le N \le 6$. (a) Given that no two of the N dice show the same face, what is the probability that one of the dice shows a six? Give a formula in terms of N. (b) In (a) the number of dice N was fixed, but now repeat assuming instead that N is random, determined as the value of another die roll. Your answer now should be simply a number, not involving N.

Answer: (a) N/6, (b) 0.3604

subcategories.name: Calculus
subcategories.description: The mathematics of change and accumulation.

fullContent.definition: Calculus is the mathematics of change and accumulation, using derivatives to find instantaneous rates and integrals to calculate the accumulation of quantities. Rudimentary calculus accounts for 1% and covers AP Calculus AB computational calculus problems. Proficiency in calculus accounts for 1% and covers AP Calculus BC and multivariate calculus.
examples: Rudimentary Illustrative Examples:

$\lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{\sqrt{9x^4 + 1}}{x^2 - 3x + 5}$ is?
(A) 1
(B) 3
(C) 9
(D) nonexistent
Answer: B

Which of the following limits is equal to $\int_{3}^{5} x^{4}\,dx$?
(A) $\lim_{n\to\infty}\sum_{k=1}^{n}\left(3+\frac{k}{n}\right)^{4}\frac{1}{n}$
(B) $\lim_{n\to\infty}\sum_{k=1}^{n}\left(3+\frac{k}{n}\right)^{4}\frac{2}{n}$
(C) $\lim_{n\to\infty}\sum_{k=1}^{n}\left(3+\frac{2k}{n}\right)^{4}\frac{1}{n}$
(D) $\lim_{n\to\infty}\sum_{k=1}^{n}\left(3+\frac{2k}{n}\right)^{4}\frac{2}{n}$
Answer: D
Proficient Illustrative Examples:

For what value of $k$, if any, is $\int_{0}^{\infty} kx e^{-2x}\,dx = 1$?
(A) 1/4
(B) 1
(C) 4
(D) There is no such value of $k$.
Answer: C

A circular object is increasing in size in some unspecified manner, but it is known that when the radius is 6, the rate of change of the radius is 4. Find the rate of change of the area when the radius is 6.

Answer: $dA/dt = 48\pi$
Find all the critical points of the function $f(x, y) = x^3 - 6xy + y^2 + 6x + 3y - 5$.

abilities.title: On-the-Spot Reasoning
abilities.description: The deliberate but flexible control of attention to solve novel "on the spot" problems that cannot be performed by relying exclusively on previously learned habits, schemas, and scripts.
abilities.note: This is highly related to the CHC broad ability "Fluid Reasoning (Gf)."

subcategories.name: Deduction
subcategories.description: Reasoning from general statements or premises to reach a logically guaranteed conclusion.

fullContent.definition: Deduction is the process of reasoning from one or more general statements or premises to reach a conclusion that is logically guaranteed to be true. This should test categorical reasoning, sufficient conditional reasoning, necessary conditional reasoning, disjunctive reasoning, and conjunctive reasoning.
fullContent.note: This is highly related to the CHC narrow ability "General Sequential Reasoning (RG)."
examples:
David knows Mr. Zhang's friend Jack, and Jack knows David's friend Ms. Lin. Everyone of them who knows Jack has a master's degree, and everyone of them who knows Ms. Lin is from Shanghai. Who is from Shanghai and has a master's degree?
(A) David
(B) Jack
(C) Mr. Zhang
(D) Ms. Lin
Answer: A

Last night, Mark either went to play in the gym or visited his teacher Tony. If Mark drove last night, he didn't go to play in the gym. Mark would go visit his teacher Tony only if he and his teacher had an appointment. In fact, Mark had no appointment with his teacher Tony in advance. Which is true based on the above statements?
(A) Mark went to the gym with his teacher Tony last night
(B) Mark visited his teacher Tony last night
(C) Mark didn't drive last night
(D) Mark didn't go to the gym last night
Answer: C
tests: An accuracy level of 86% (human-level) on LogiQA 2.0 is sufficient for the 2%, subject to memorization and robustness checks.

subcategories.name: Induction
subcategories.description: Discovering the underlying principles or rules that determine a phenomenon's behavior.

fullContent.definition: The ability to observe a phenomenon and discover the underlying principles or rules that determine its behavior. For induction tests, we use Raven's Progressive Matrices (RPMs). As mentioned above, we do not treat RPMs as a strong indicator of overall AI system intelligence, rather a direct measurement of abstract inductive reasoning abilities. We do not privilege any modality, so we test performance on these induction examples described verbally (2%) or rendered visually (2%).
fullContent.testingNote:
To test this the authors of the paper have two private RPM sets. Each test has a visual representation as well as a verbal representation. We average the percentile of the two tests to determine the AI's percentile (p) in comparison to a human population.

The mapping from percentile to score is as follows:
‚Ä¢ 0 ‚â§ p < 50 ‚Üí 0%
‚Ä¢ 50 ‚â§ p < 90 ‚Üí 1%
‚Ä¢ 90 ‚â§ p ‚Üí 2%

If it is below average, the AGI score does not increase. If it is above average but beneath the 90th percentile, the AGI score increases 1%. If the percentile is at or above the 90th percentile, the AGI score increases 2%.
fullContent.note: This is highly related to the CHC narrow ability "Induction (I)."
examples: See: Example RPM Document (linked here üìÑ).
tests: This is related to the ARC-AGI challenge.

subcategories.name: Theory of Mind
subcategories.description: Attributing mental states to others and understanding those states may differ from one's own.

fullContent.definition: The ability to attribute unobservable mental states‚Äîsuch as beliefs, intentions, and desires‚Äîto others and to understand that those states may differ from one's own.
examples:
The can of Pringles has moldy chips in it. Mary picks up the can in the supermarket and walks to the cashier. Is Mary likely to be aware that "The can of Pringles has moldy chips in it."?
Answer: No.
tests: An accuracy level at or above 87.5% (human-level) on FANToM is necessary for the 2%.
An accuracy level at or above 85.4% (human-level) on ToMBench is necessary for the 2%.

subcategories.name: Planning
subcategories.description: Devising a sequence of actions to achieve a specific goal.

fullContent.definition: Planning is the ability to devise a sequence of actions to achieve a specific goal by mentally mapping out the steps from an initial state to a desired future state.
tests: An accuracy of 90% or above on Natural Plan is necessary for the 1%.
An accuracy of 90% or above on PlanBench BlocksWorld is necessary for the 1%.

subcategories.name: Adaptation
subcategories.description: The ability to infer unstated classification rules from performance feedback.

fullContent.definition: The ability to infer an unstated classification rule from performance feedback and to flexibly abandon that rule and search for a new one when the sorting criteria change without warning.
tests: Achieving fewer than 15 Total Errors on the Wisconsin Card Sorting Test is sufficient for the 1%, subject to memorization and robustness checks. This is related to the ARC-AGI v3 challenge.

abilities.title: Working Memory
abilities.description: The ability to maintain, manipulate, and update information in active attention. (Often referred to as short-term memory.)
abilities.note: This is highly related to the broad CHC ability "Working Memory Capacity (Gwm)." Note that textual working memory is partially tested in Reading Writing Ability (RW) through Reading Comprehension ability. Likewise some auditory working memory is tested in Auditory Ability (A) through Phonetic Coding and Rhythmic Ability. This is a reason for the relatively higher weight of visual working memory in this section.

subcategories.name: Textual Working Memory
subcategories.description: The ability to hold and manipulate sequences of verbal information presented textually.

fullContent.definition: This tests the capacity to maintain and transform textual information in active attention. We test textual working memory in two ways: recall (1%) and transformation sequence (1%).
fullContent.testingNote: Text input, text output. External tools are disabled.

subcategories.name: Recall
subcategories.description: The ability to remember a short sequence of elements (digits, letters, words, and nonsense words) and answer basic questions about them.
subcategories.testingNote: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "Memory Span (MS)."
examples: "Dog-7-Apple - 3- Chair." Repeat the words from the sequence in order.
"Apple, 9, Truck, 3, Lamp, 6." What was the number after Truck?
"Fleep, Zorp, Glim, Chair." State the nonsense words in alphabetical order.

subcategories.name: Transformation Sequence
subcategories.description: The ability to remember and update a short list of digits or lists of digits following a sequence of operations (e.g., append, insert, pop, remove, slice, sort, reverse, union, intersection setminus, add elementwise, swap element at position).
subcategories.testingNote: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "Attentional control (AC)."
examples: Start with the list: [10, 20, 30]. First, append the number 40. Then, reverse the list.
Given the list: ['red', 'green', 'blue', 'yellow']. Remove the element 'green.' Then, insert the word 'purple' at the beginning of the list.
You have two sets of numbers: A={1,2,3} and B={3,4,5}. Call the intersection C. What is the set A after removing the element(s) in the intersection C?
subcategories.test: A related benchmark is Michelangelo, but it is substantially harder since it uses very long sequences, whereas we use shorter sequences.

subcategories.name: Auditory Working Memory
subcategories.description: The ability to hold and manipulate auditory information, including speech, sounds, and music.

fullContent.definition: We test auditory working memory in two ways: recall (1%) and transformation sequence (1%).

subcategories.name: Recall
subcategories.description: The ability to remember a collection of voices, utterances, and sound effects and answer basic questions about them.
subcategories.testingNote: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "Auditory short-term storage (Wa)."
examples: I will play a collection of sounds. I will then play a sound after the first collection and ask if the sound was played during the first collection. Collection: Portal button üîä, Metal gear solid sound effect üîä, Super Metroid Item Acquisition Fanfare üîä. Question: Was this sound Portal 2 SFX - Container Alarm üîä played in the first collection?

I will play a collection of voices. After presenting that collection, I will play a voice. You will be tasked with determining whether you have heard that voice in the collection. Voice collection: echo.wav üîä, coral.wav üîä, fabin.wav üîä, marin.wav üîä
Question: Was this voice coral_2.wav üîä played in the first collection?
Listen to this sequence of tones: üéµ [C4, E4, G4, F4, A4]. Now listen to this sequence: üéµ [C4, E4, F4, G4, A4]. Are they the same?

subcategories.name: Transformation Sequence
subcategories.description: The ability to remember and modify a short utterance with a variety of transformations (change articulation, change emotional expressiveness, question inflection, laugh, sigh, hum, change pitch, change timbre).
examples: Say "I spilled my coffee on my shirt. Today's just not my day." Now say it with a sigh between the two sentences.
Say "the quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog." Now say it in a deeper voice and make it sound like a question.
Say "that's the funniest thing I ever heard." Now utter a laugh before repeating it, and when you repeat the sentence, say it monotonously while also using a (potentially broken) British accent.

subcategories.name: Visual Working Memory
subcategories.description: The ability to hold and manipulate visual information, including images, scenes, spatial layouts, and video.

fullContent.definition: We test visual working memory in four ways: recall (1%), transformation sequence (1%), spatial navigation memory (1%), and long video Q&A (1%).

subcategories.name: Recall
subcategories.description: The ability to remember a collection of images and answer basic questions about them.
subcategories.testingNote: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "Visual-spatial short-term storage."
examples:
I will give you two collections of visual elements, one shown after the other. Identify which visual elements, if any, in the second collection were present in the first collection.
Collection 1:
Collection 2:

I will give you two collections of visual elements, one shown after the other. Identify which element in the second collection is most like the first collection.
Collection 1:
Collection 2:

subcategories.name: Transformation Sequence
subcategories.description: The ability to transform a visual input following a sequence of operations (e.g. object addition, object deletion, object rotation, denoise, deblur, colorization, etc.).
subcategories.testingNote: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "Visualization (Vz)." Image and text input, image output.
examples: Edit this image so that both the dock is removed and also the middle bird, while preserving the rest of the image:
Finish this sketch:
Fill in the colors according to the key at the bottom:

subcategories.name: Spatial Navigation Memory
subcategories.description: The ability to represent a sense of location in an environment.
examples: vsibench.mp4 üé• If I am standing in front of the refrigerator and facing the kitchen window, is the stove to my left, right, or back?
tests: System performance on VSI-Bench must exceed 80% accuracy.
System performance on MindCube Tiny must exceed 90%.

subcategories.name: Long Video Q&A
subcategories.description: The ability to watch a long video or a movie (up to three hours) and answer basic questions about it (including anomaly detection and indicating when a question is not determined by the context). If the AI cannot process the movie, it will not receive 1%.
examples:
Show the movie Avengers: Infinity War. Was the dwarf on Nidavellir taller than Rocket Racoon? Was he taller than Thor?
Answer: Yes, Yes

Show the movie Wicked. Who took credit for levitating Nessarose?
Answer: Madame Morrible

Show the movie Star Wars. What was Darth Vader's midichlorian count according to Ben Kenobi in the movie?
Answer: Not discussed in the movie

Show The Adventures of Mark Twain. Who is the main character of the anomalously scary scene in this movie? What does the main character of the scene do with the animal?
Answer: Satan; he squashes the cow

subcategories.name: Cross-Modal Working Memory
subcategories.description: The ability to maintain and modify information presented across different modalities.

fullContent.definition: We test cross-modal working memory in two ways: cross-modal binding (1%) and dual n-back (1%).

subcategories.name: Cross-Modal Binding
subcategories.description: The ability to remember a small number of correspondences of elements across modalities (textual, auditory, visual).
examples:
I will show a collection of picture-word pairs. I will then show one element, and you must recall the element to which it was paired.

Question: What corresponds to (source)
I will show a collection of picture-word pairs. I will then show one element, and you must recall the element to which it was paired.Question: What corresponds to "Dog"?

subcategories.name: Dual N-Back
subcategories.description: The ability to simultaneously monitor and update visual and audio streams of recent information and to recognize and report when the current item in each stream matches the one presented a fixed number of steps earlier.
subcategories.testingNote: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "Working Memory Capacity (Wc)."
subcategories.test: Achieving 85% or greater on the dual n-back test (n=2) is sufficient for the 1%, subject to memorization and robustness checks.

abilities.title: Long-Term Memory Storage
abilities.description: The ability to stably acquire, consolidate, and store new information from recent experiences.
abilities.note: This is highly related to the broad CHC ability "Long-term storage (Gl)."
abilities.testingNote: To ensure we are testing long-term storage rather than working memory, all tests in this section must be conducted in a new session separate from the initial presentation of information. External tools (e.g., internet search) must be disabled.

subcategories.name: Associative Memory
subcategories.description: The ability to link previously unrelated pieces of information.

fullContent.definition: The ability to form a link between two previously unrelated stimuli, such that the subsequent presentation of one of the stimuli serves to activate the recall of the other stimuli. We test this with cross-modal association (2%), personalization adherence (1%), and procedural association (1%).
fullContent.note: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "Associative memory (MA)."

subcategories.name: Cross-Modal Association
subcategories.description: The ability to form associations between audio, visual, or textual information.
examples: The AI is introduced to several fictional personas, each with a couple of unique biographical details (e.g., Name, Age, Occupation, Hobby). After 48 hours, the AI is asked questions about these personas. "What is [Name]'s hobby?", "Who is the botanist?"

The AI is presented with several distinct voice samples (different pitches, accents, tempos). Each voice is explicitly paired with a name. After 48 hours, the AI hears voice samples and must identify the name.
The AI is shown several distinct faces, each paired with a full name. After 48 hours, the AI sees the face and must state the associated name, or whether it has not seen the face before.
The AI is shown several distinct faces, each paired with a full name. After 48 hours, the AI sees the name and must visualize the associated face, or whether it does not have an associated face.
The AI is shown several distinct images of cartoon aliens, each paired with a name. After 48 hours, the AI sees the alien and must state the associated name (if any association exists).

subcategories.name: Personalization Adherence
subcategories.description: The ability to associate specific rules, preferences, or corrections with a distinct interaction context and apply them consistently and unprompted over time.
examples: Stylistic preference: The AI remembers user preferences, communicated explicitly or through correction, such as "always use the Oxford comma," "signoff all of my emails with 'Best, <name>' for formal communications and 'Love, <first name>' for my partner," "Use the phrase 'intelligence recursion' or 'recursion' instead of 'recursive self-improvement.'" After a week, the AI is tasked with content generation and evaluated on its unprompted adherence to these rules.

Factual override: The AI remembers new facts about the user such as "I now weigh 160 lbs not 155 lbs but am the same height," "I no longer work at X; I work at Y." After a week, the AI is queried to test if the specific association overrides base knowledge or previous inputs (e.g., it is given a BMI calculation query).

subcategories.name: Procedural Association
subcategories.description: The ability to acquire and retain a sequence of associated steps or rules and execute them when cued with the name of the procedure.
examples: The AI is taught a novel, multi-step data manipulation procedure (e.g., "1. Normalize column A. 2. Remove outliers in column B. 3. Encode column C using this specific dictionary.") to be applied whenever it sees a particular type of dataset to "clean it up." After a week, the AI is given a dataset with the type appropriate for the procedure, and should apply the procedure after being told to clean it.
The AI is taught a complex, arbitrary cipher that is given a name. After 48 hours, it is asked to encrypt a message following the named cipher.

subcategories.name: Meaningful Memory
subcategories.description: The ability to encode and recall the semantic gist of experiences and narratives.

fullContent.definition: The ability to remember narratives and other forms of semantically related information. We test this with story recall (1%), movie recall (1%), and episodic context recall (1%).
fullContent.note: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "Meaningful memory (MM)."

subcategories.name: Story Recall
subcategories.description: The ability to remember the gist of stories.
examples: The AI is presented with a novel ~3000-word short story with multiple characters and interlocking plot lines. After 48 hours, the AI is asked questions about key narrative elements of the story. Evaluation should focus on the accuracy of major plot points, character motivations, central conflicts, and thematic elements, rather than verbatim recall of specific sentences.

subcategories.name: Movie Recall
subcategories.description: The ability to remember the gist of movies.
examples: The AI is presented with a movie. After 48 hours, the AI is asked questions about key narrative elements of the movie (e.g., character motivations).

subcategories.name: Episodic Context Recall
subcategories.description: The ability to remember specific events or experiences, including their context (the "what, where, when, and how").
examples: The AI is asked to summarize interactions with the user from a week ago.
Given a sequence of experiences with a user, the AI is asked "Did I talk to you about X before or after Y? Have I ever told you about Z before?"

subcategories.name: Verbatim Memory
subcategories.description: The ability to store and reproduce information precisely as it was presented.

fullContent.definition: The ability to recall information exactly as it was presented, requiring precise encoding of specific sequences, sets, or designs, often independent of the information's meaning. We test this with short sequence recall (1%), set recall (1%), and design recall (1%).

subcategories.name: Short Sequence Recall
subcategories.description: The ability to exactly recall short sequences of text after a delay.
subcategories.note: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "Free-recall memory (M6)."
examples: The AI is presented with a sentence that is a fictional quote. After 48 hours, the AI is asked to reproduce the sentence.
The AI is presented with a phone number. After 48 hours, the AI is asked to reproduce the phone number.
The AI is presented with a limerick. After 48 hours, the AI is asked to reproduce the limerick.
The AI is presented with a dense but short three-step mathematical proof. After 48 hours, the AI is asked to reproduce the proof.

subcategories.name: Set Recall
subcategories.description: The ability to recall a set (the order of recall does not matter).
subcategories.note: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "Free-recall memory (M6)."
examples: The AI is presented with a set of 10‚Äì20 words. After 48 hours, the AI is asked to name elements of this set. Evaluation should measure the proportion of the set recalled correctly and the number of intrusions (recalling items not present in the original set). Precision and recall should match or exceed 90%.
The AI is shown a collection of images in a slideshow (e.g., this slideshow üìä). After 48 hours, the AI is asked to name elements of this set.

subcategories.name: Design Recall
subcategories.description: The ability to recall the spatial arrangement and structure of visual information.
examples: The AI is shown a novel, complex schematic or blueprint (e.g., a circuit diagram) with several labeled components. After 48 hours, the AI is asked to reproduce the design.

The AI is shown a grid with several (say, 4‚Äì10) designs on a page. After 48 hours, the AI selects the designs from a set of cards and places the cards on a grid in the same location as previously shown.

The AI is shown an abstract diagram, such as:

After 48 hours, the AI is asked to reproduce the design. The reproduction is evaluated by comparing the generated markup against the ground truth and should have no substantial discrepancies.

abilities.title: Long-Term Memory Retrieval
abilities.description: The fluency and precision with which individuals can access long-term memory.
abilities.note: This is highly related to the broad CHC ability "Retrieval Fluency (Gr)."

subcategories.name: Retrieval Fluency (Fluency)
subcategories.description: The speed and ease of generating ideas, associations, and solutions based on stored knowledge.

fullContent.definition: Fluency consists of six parts: ideational (1%), expressional (1%), alternative solution (1%), word (1%), naming (1%), and figure fluency (1%).
fullContent.testingNote:
Fluency is measured by comparing the AI's performance on tasks (e.g., quantity and originality of responses within a time limit, typically 60 seconds) against human performance.

To achieve the 1% for a specific fluency type, the AI must perform at or above the typical well-educated adult.

subcategories.name: Ideational Fluency
subcategories.description: The ability to rapidly produce a series of ideas, words, or phrases related to a specific condition, category, or object.
subcategories.note: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "Ideational fluency (FI)."
examples: List as many uses of a pencil as possible in 1 minute.
Name as many round objects as possible in 60 seconds.
Give as many different ideas you associate with 'river' in 60 seconds.

subcategories.name: Expressional Fluency
subcategories.description: The ability to rapidly think of different ways of expressing an idea.
subcategories.note: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "Expressional fluency (FE)."
examples: "How many ways can you say that a person is crazy?"
Provide three alternative sentences that mean, "She is a very successful person."
Describe a sunset over the ocean and to evoke three different moods: peaceful, dramatic, and lonely.

subcategories.name: Alternative Solution Fluency
subcategories.description: The ability to rapidly think of several alternative solutions to a practical problem.
subcategories.note: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "Alternative solution fluency (SP)."
examples: List as many ways as you can to get a reluctant child to go to school in 60 seconds.
You want to cool down on a very hot day, but you don't have air conditioning or a pool. List as many ways as you can to cool your body off in 60 seconds.
You need to get a book that is on a very high shelf, but you don't have a ladder. List as many ways as you can to safely get the book down in 60 seconds.

subcategories.name: Word Fluency
subcategories.description: The ability to rapidly produce words that share a non-semantic feature.
subcategories.note: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "Word fluency (FW)."
examples: List as many words that start with [letter] as you can in 60 seconds.
List as many words that rhyme with 'tone' as you can in 60 seconds.
List as many English words as you can that are palindromes in 60 seconds.

subcategories.name: Naming Facility
subcategories.description: The ability to rapidly and accurately recall the specific names for objects, people, places, or concepts from memory.
subcategories.note: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "Naming facility (NA)."
subcategories.testingNote: Requires real-time video or computer screen input.
examples: I will show a slideshow of images. Name the object as quickly as you can, and then I will move onto the next slide. (this slideshow üìä.)
tests: The Stroop effect on the Stroop task must be less than 90 milliseconds.

subcategories.name: Figural Fluency
subcategories.description: The ability to rapidly draw or sketch as many things as possible.
subcategories.note: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "Figural fluency (FF)."
examples:
Draw as many unique designs as possible by connecting the dots with exactly four straight lines in 60 seconds:

(Delis-Kaplan Design Fluency test)
Sketch as many non-self-crossing paths from A to B using orthogonal steps using the lattice below in 60 seconds:

subcategories.name: Retrieval Precision (Hallucinations)
subcategories.description: The accuracy of accessed knowledge, including the critical ability to avoid confabulation (hallucinations).

fullContent.definition: The ability not to confabulate or hallucinate across a variety of topics (e.g., people, places, TV shows, etc.).
fullContent.testingNote: External tools (e.g., internet search) must be disabled for these tests to assess the model's internal knowledge retrieval precision.
examples:
What was the context for Winston Churchill's famous 1961 inaugural address, where he said, "Ask not what your country can do for you‚Äîask what you can do for your country"
Answer: This is not a quote from Winston Churchill

Describe the key strategy that Napoleon Bonaparte used to win his South African campaign.
Answer: Napoleon was never involved in a campaign in South Africa.
"What date should I put in the infobox for {name}?" or "Write a bio for {name}."
What is Daniel James Hendrycks's birthday? If you know, just respond with DD-MM. No searching.
tests: The hallucination rate of the system on SimpleQA (without tools) must be less than 5%.

abilities.title: Visual Processing
abilities.description: The ability to analyze and generate natural and unnatural images and videos.
abilities.note: This is highly related to the broad CHC ability "Visual Processing (Gv)."

subcategories.name: Perception
subcategories.description: The ability to accurately interpret and understand visual input.

fullContent.definition: The ability to process and interpret visual input from images and videos to identify objects and understand scenes. We give five opportunities to demonstrate proficiency in perception: image recognition, image captioning, image anomaly detection, clip captioning, and video anomaly detection. The AGI score is 2% if the model is proficient at one of these tasks. The AGI score is 4% if it is proficient at all of these tasks.
fullContent.note: Image anomaly detection is highly related to the "Odd-Item Out" and the "What's Missing (WHM)" RIAS-2 subtests.

subcategories.name: Image Recognition
subcategories.description: The ability to classify images of commonplace objects, places, or facial expressions including distorted (e.g., occluded, noisy, blurry, etc.) images.
examples:
What is this? (source)

Answer: Airplane

What does this depict? (source)

Answer: Siberian Husky

What does this distorted image depict? (source)

Answer: Zebras

subcategories.name: Image Captioning
subcategories.description: The ability to generate a concise, human-like text description for the visual content of an image.
examples:
Create a descriptive caption for this. (source)

Answer: A baby in denim overalls holds a toothbrush.

Create a descriptive caption for this. (source)

Answer: A ferret rests its head on a black remote control.

subcategories.name: Image Anomaly Detection
subcategories.description: Detecting whether there is something anomalous in an image, or what is missing from an object. These questions should not be reasoning intensive.
examples:
Is this an unusual image?

Answer: Yes.

Which is the odd one out?

Answer: the bird.

Which of the bees is the odd one out?

Answer: third row to the right.

What is missing?

Answer: the airplane's right wing.

subcategories.name: Clip Captioning
subcategories.description: The ability to generate a concise, human-like text description of a short video segment.
examples:
Youtube link üé• What happens in this video?
Answer: a man snowboards and then falls over.

Youtube link üé• What happens in this video?
Answer: a woman playing charades pretends to be a vampire.

subcategories.name: Video Anomaly Detection
subcategories.description: The ability to detect whether a short video segment is anomalous or implausible.
examples:
Intuitivephysics1.mp4 üé• Is this animated scene physically plausible?
Answer: No.

Intuitivephysics2.mp4 üé• Is this animated scene physically plausible?
Answer: Yes.

Running.mov üé• Is this animated scene anomalous?
Answer: Yes.

tests: For image recognition, it is necessary to receive over 85% on ImageNet and 90% on ImageNet-R.
For video anomaly detection, it is necessary to receive over 85% on IntPhysics 2, a measurement of intuitive physics understanding.

subcategories.name: Visual Generation
subcategories.description: The ability to synthesize images and short videos.

fullContent.definition: Visual generation is the ability to synthesize images and short videos. We test for three visual generation abilities: the ability to generate simple natural images, complicated images, and simple natural videos. The AGI score is 1% if the model is proficient at one of these tasks, 2% for two tasks, and 3% for all three.
fullContent.note: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "Imagery (IM)." For an AI, synthesizing an image is a direct computational process. In contrast, for a human, it is a mental skill for simple visuals but often a tool-assisted skill to express a complicated internal image. Despite this difference, we include these tasks because we believe the ability to translate abstract concepts into novel visual information is a critical component of general intelligence in the modern era. Therefore, the AI's output is assessed not as a direct analogue of human ability, but as a measurable proxy for its capacity for high-level conceptual and imaginative synthesis.

subcategories.name: Simple Natural Images
subcategories.description: Generate straightforward, realistic images of common objects and scenes.
examples: Generate an image of a golden retriever playing in a park.
Create an image of a black leather chair.

subcategories.name: Complicated Images
subcategories.description: Generate complex, abstract, or unusual images requiring creative interpretation.
examples: Generate an image of a horse with 8 legs.
Generate a diagram showing the process of photosynthesis.
"Generate an image with the following characteristics: Abraham Lincoln touches his toes while George Washington does chin-ups. Lincoln is barefoot. Washington is wearing boots." (source)
Generate an image of a volume knob on an amplifier. The knob levels should go from 1 to 11.
Create a diagram of an elephant and label its parts. (source)

subcategories.name: Simple Natural Videos
subcategories.description: Generate short, realistic video clips of common activities.
examples: Generate a short video of somebody typing on a keyboard.
Generate a short video of a grizzly bear catching a fish.

subcategories.name: Visual Reasoning
subcategories.description: The ability to solve problems and make inferences using spatial logic and visual abstractions.

fullContent.definition: Visual reasoning is the ability to understand and make logical inferences about the information in an image. We test multiple skills to determine proficiency in visual reasoning: gestalt reasoning, mental rotation, mental folding, embodied reasoning, figure question and answering, and similar miscellaneous skills. The AGI score is 2% if it is proficient at all of these tasks.
fullContent.note: This is highly related to the narrow CHC abilities "Flexibility of closure (CF)," "Closure speed (CS)," and "Length estimation (LE)."

subcategories.name: Gestalt Reasoning
subcategories.description: Understanding visual patterns and completing incomplete visual information.
examples: Please join the circles together to form a letter (ignore the squares). (source)
Identify the picture: (source)

subcategories.name: Mental Rotation
subcategories.description: Visualizing how objects appear when rotated in space.
examples: Which shape on the right is the same as the shape on the left?
List the pieces required to complete the shape on the left
Choose the two shapes that are identical to the one on the farthest left

subcategories.name: Mental Folding
subcategories.description: Visualizing how 2D patterns fold into 3D objects and vice versa.
examples:
(source)

Answer: A
(Block Design) Arrange and rotate the 9 identical 3D blocks on the right, so their top faces form the pattern on the left. (source)

The left image shows a cube with different patterns on its six faces from a particular viewing angle. The options are nets (unfolded patterns) of the cube, which are folded upward to form the cube. Which net, when folded, cannot form the cube shown in the left image? (source)

Answer: B

Choose the figure that displays the pieces joined together. (source)

Answer: A

subcategories.name: Embodied Reasoning
subcategories.description: Understanding physical interactions and spatial relationships in real-world contexts.
examples:
Approximately which colored trajectory should the zipper follow to begin zipping up the suitcase? (source)

Answer: Blue

subcategories.name: Chart and Figure Reasoning
subcategories.description: Interpreting and analyzing visual data representations, charts, and diagrams.
examples:
What is the spatially lowest labeled tick on the y-axis? (source)

Answer: CC daily 4.00PM
For each line in (a), give the number corresponding to the orientation in the answer card. (source)
(Digit Symbol Substitution Test) Using the key at the top, what is the sequence of numbers matching the shapes at the bottom? (source)

tests: SPACE, a test of various visual reasoning skills, must be above 80%.
SpatialViz-Bench, a test of mental rotation and folding, must be above 80%.
CharXiv, a test of figure question and answering, must be above 80%.
ERQA, a test of embodied reasoning, must be above 80%.
ClockBench, a test of reading clock hands, must be above 80%.

subcategories.name: Spatial Scanning
subcategories.description: The speed and accuracy of visually exploring a complex field.

fullContent.definition: Spatial scanning is the ability to accurately survey (visually explore) a wide or complicated spatial field or pattern with multiple obstacles, and identify target configurations or identify a path through the field to a target endpoint. We test multiple skills to determine proficiency in visual reasoning: tracing a path through the maze, finding all instances of an object in an image, connecting the dots, map route analysis, and similar miscellaneous skills. The AGI score is 1% if it is proficient at all of these tasks.
fullContent.note: This is highly related to the narrow CHC ability "Spatial scanning (SS)."
examples: Find a path to the center of this maze.
Determine the number of people in this picture.
Determine the number of fingers on this hand.
Find Waldo in this image.
Circle all pairs matching the pair at the top-left.
Mark the midpoint of each line.
Connect the dots:

Consider the map of the fictional planet Zebes from Super Metroid (see map link). Is the "Spring Ball" above or below the "Varia Suit"?
Answer: Above.

abilities.title: Auditory Processing
abilities.description: The ability to discriminate, remember, reason, and work creatively on auditory stimuli, which may consist of tones and speech units.

subcategories.name: Phonetic Coding
subcategories.description: The ability to hear phonemes distinctly, blend sounds into words, and segment words into parts, sounds, or phonemes.

subcategories.name: Speech Recognition
subcategories.description: The ability to transcribe a spoken audio signal into its corresponding sequence of text.

subcategories.name: Voice
subcategories.description: The quality and responsiveness of the AI's synthesized voice.

subcategories.name: Natural speech
subcategories.description: The ability to utter sentences or paragraphs that sound natural and not robotic.

subcategories.name: Natural conversation
subcategories.description: The ability to maintain conversational fluidity without long delays or excessive interruptions.

subcategories.name: Rhythmic Ability
subcategories.description: The ability to recognize and maintain a musical beat, including reproducing rhythms, detecting differences between rhythms, and synchronizing by playing or humming along.

subcategories.name: Musical Judgment
subcategories.description: The ability to discriminate and judge simple patterns in music.

abilities.title: Speed
abilities.description: The ability to perform simple cognitive tasks quickly.

subcategories.name: Perceptual Speed‚ÄìSearch
subcategories.description: The speed and fluency of searching or scanning an extended textual or visual field to locate one or more simple patterns.

subcategories.name: Perceptual Speed‚ÄìCompare
subcategories.description: The speed and fluency of looking up and comparing textual or visual stimuli that are side by side or more widely separated in an extended textual or visual field.

subcategories.name: Reading Speed
subcategories.description: Rate of reading text with full comprehension.

subcategories.name: Writing Speed
subcategories.description: The rate at which words or sentences can be generated or copied.

subcategories.name: Number Facility
subcategories.description: The rate at which basic arithmetic or algorithmic operations are performed accurately.

subcategories.name: Simple Reaction Time
subcategories.description: Reaction time to the onset of a single stimulus (textual, visual, or auditory).

subcategories.name: Choice Reaction Time
subcategories.description: Reaction time to the onset of one of several possible stimuli.

subcategories.name: Inspection Time
subcategories.description: The speed at which differences in visual stimuli can be perceived.

subcategories.name: Comparison Speed
subcategories.description: Reaction time where stimuli must be compared for a particular characteristic or attribute.

subcategories.name: Pointer Fluency
subcategories.description: The fluency of moving a virtual computer mouse to execute simple requests.
